items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.      
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Please note there is potential for levels to rise again tomorrow afternoon, Sunday 9th January. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

River levels have risen at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between 4pm today, Saturday 08/01/22 and Monday 10/01/22. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech 3.7 to 4m this evening, Saturday 08/01/22; Cae Howel 4.2 to 4.5m Sunday morning, 09/01/22. Further showers are forecast over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 09/01/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to continue rising at the Basford Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall this morning. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from this evening and into tomorrow, Sunday, 09/01/2022. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle. Further heavy showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high into tomorrow Sunday 09/01/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 09/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from midnight tonight. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn  bankfull at White Abbey. Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green 5.2 to 5.5m Sunday morning. No other gauge locations are expected to reach their flood alert threshold. Further showers are forecast over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on Sunday 09/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. Water levels are continuing to remain high following recent tide locking. This combined with rainfall is likely to increase levels further. Levels are likely to remain high through today Saturday 8th January and into tomorrow. Water levels are expected to continue to rise gradually over the next few hours. This is due to a natural tide locking effect combined with today's rainfall. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 9th January.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Hay-On-Wye, Bredwardine, Belmont, Old Wye Bridge & Mordiford river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin from this evening Saturday 08/01/22.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye.  Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye 1.8m to 2.1m Saturday evening 08/01/22. Bredwardine 3.5m to 3.8m, Belmont 3.1m to 3.8m, Old Wye Bridge 2.8m to 3.3m & Mordiford 3.1m to 3.6m Sunday morning.
Further showers are forecast over the weekend.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 09/01/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses & avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10am on Sunday 09/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: River levels have risen at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between 19:30 and 23:00 today, 08/01/22.  We expect flooding to affect the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow, 09/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and closing flood gates. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 09/01/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels are rising at the Tern – Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin this evening Saturday, 08/01/22.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   
Further showers are forecast over the weekend.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 09/01/22. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10am on Sunday 09/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Please note there is potential for levels to rise again tomorrow afternoon, Sunday 9th January. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

High water levels with sea spray are forecast as a result of high tides and increased wind speeds. First forecast high water is 23:00 on 8/1/22 with a level of 4.21 mAOD and a Force 7 North Westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 11:30 on 9/1/22 with a level of 4.27 mAOD and a Force 6 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Coastal conditions should ease for the 9/1/22 high tide at 23:45. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 12:00 tomorrow on Sunday, 9/1/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Saturday 8th January. 
Heavy rain over the last 24 hours has caused river levels in the catchments of the River Clyst and River Culm to rise. 
Further showers are forecast overnight and throughout the next few days which will cause river levels to remain higher than normal.
We expect flooding to affect to low lying land and roads at Cullompton, Willand, Culmstock, Hemyock, Bradninch, Broadclyst and Clyst St. Mary. 
Please take care near the areas of concern. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded. 
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation.
This message will be updated on Sunday morning.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible from 2pm on Saturday 8th January. Heavy rain has been falling on saturated ground throughout the morning and river levels are rising. This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers later this afternoon, particularly in the Tamarstone Bridge and Crowford Bridge areas. However, flooding to properties is not currently expected.  

We expect rivers to peak during the afternoon today and remain high throughout the remainder of Saturday and into Sunday morning. Further heavy showers are forecast for the rest of the weekend. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Sunday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels are rising at the Beggearn Huish river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this evening, 08/01/22.  We expect flooding to affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to continue to rise this evening, 08/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and closing flood gates. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 09/01/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels are rising slowly on the Bristol Avon at Bradford-on-Avon and on the Semington Brook at Semington.
Only small amounts of rain are forecast for the next few days and rivers are expected to peak on Sunday morning, before levels gradually drop.
No Flood Warnings are currently forecast for this area.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated on Sunday morning.

River levels are reacting as a result of the heavy rainfall earlier today, 08/01/2022, which is making its way downstream. Areas most risk are low lying land, and we are already seeing the washlands at Snaygill Ings, Skipton and Cononley filling.

River levels on the Aire are peaking and not expected to rise significantly further but will cause filling of Snaygill Ings, Skipton and Cononley  to continue this evening, 08/01/2022.

River levels are expected to drop later tonight which will allow the washlands to start to drain, but please be aware that standing water will remain for some time. No significant further rainfall is forecast this weekend and we expect river levels to continue to fall throughout the rest of Saturday (08/01/2022) and Sunday (09/01/2022). 

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourse and do not drive through flood water.

This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

This flood alert is no longer in force. River levels have peaked at Earby Beck and are now falling below levels of concern. There may be scattered showers through the rest of today and tomorrow, however no further significant rainfall is forecast this weekend and we expect river levels to be able to continue to fall throughout the rest of Saturday and Sunday.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
This warning is no longer in force. River levels have peaked at Walsden Water at levels below those forecasted, and are now falling below levels of concern. There may be scattered showers this evening, 08/01/2022, but these will be much less intense than this morning's rainfall and are not expected to cause a significant river level response.
 
No further significant rainfall is forecast this weekend and we expect river levels to be able to continue to fall throughout the rest of Saturday and Sunday.

items.message: The risk of flooding in the North Devon area has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
